Graphical abstract Bimetallic Cu–Zn electrocatalysts have emerged as promising candidates for selectively reducing carbon dioxide (CO2) to ethanol. While CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) has been studied extensively on monometallic Cu and Zn catalysts and their homogenous alloys, the influence of heterogeneous Cu–Zn interfaces remain underexplored. Herein, we used density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the interface effects of phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts on CO2RR toward ethanol. Interface sites significantly modulate intermediate stability and enhance the C–C coupling step, particularly CO–CH coupling, which is both thermodynamically and kinetically favorable (ΔG rxn = −1.28 eV; ΔG ‡ = 0.27 eV). Interface site favors the ethanol pathway over ethylene after subsequent *CHCO formation. Microkinetic analysis further suggests that CO–CH coupling dominantly contributes to the ethanol production. These findings reveal the cooperative role of interface sites in enabling selective ethanol production, providing insights into the rational design of Cu–Zn electrocatalysts. Keywords Bimetallic Cu–Zn electrocatalysts CO2RR Ethanol production Interface DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is among the promising methods for CO2 conversion to value-added products such as carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), and ethanol (C2H5OH) [1–3]. Among these, ethanol is particularly desirable due to its applications in energy, pharmaceuticals, and food industries [4]. Cu-based bimetallic catalysts have demonstrated improved selectivity for ethanol production. [5–7]. For example, in Cu–Ag systems, Ag acts as a CO promoter that enables CO insertion into CHx, supporting ethanol formation [8]. The secondary metal in bimetallic catalysts may also alter surface electronic structures, create new active sites, and stabilize key intermediates such as *CH3CHO and *HCCHOH [9,10]. Nevertheless, the C2H5OH selectivity remains relatively low for bimetallic Cu-based catalysts [6], motivating further investigation into catalyst design. The structural properties of Cu-based bimetallic catalysts, including surface composition and atomic arrangements, strongly influence CO2RR selectivity [4,5,8,10–12]. Notably, integrating Zn into Cu enhances ethanol yield [13–15]. Experimental studies show that phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts significantly boost Faradaic efficiency (FE) for ethanol [13–15], particularly those with ∼25 % Zn content with 29.1 %FE at −1.05 V vs. RHE [13]. Zn was proposed to act as the CO promoter, which then couples CHx on Cu to ethanol [13,16]. Despite these advances, the role of interface sites within phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts remain poorly understood. Herein, we theoretically explored how Cu–Zn interfaces influence CO2RR mechanisms and selectivity toward ethanol. Our model features a Zn cluster supported on a Cu(111) surface, providing Cu, Zn, and interfacial active sites. We examined the effects of interface active sites on CO and CH4 formation, C–C coupling reactions, ethanol production, and hydrogen evolution reaction. To further support the mechanistic insights, microkinetic modeling was employed to determine dominant pathways, revealing that CO–CH coupling at the interface is not only energetically favored but also kinetically dominant for ethanol production. These findings underline the crucial role of Cu–Zn interfaces in steering selectivity toward ethanol and provide design principles for optimizing bimetallic catalyst systems. 2 Computational details All calculations were carried out using spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) method as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4) [17]. The projector-augmented-wave (PAW) method [18,19] was used to treat the ion–electron interactions. The valence-electron wavefunctions were expanded in the plane-wave fashion with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV. The exchange and correlation energy were described using the Revised Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (RPBE) functional [20], which has shown been used for studying CO2RR mechanisms on various metal surfaces [21–23]. Van der Waals interactions were accounted for using Grimme's DFT-D3 schemes [24]. A dipole correction in the normal direction was included. Solvation effects were described using the implicit VASPsol model [25], which efficiently captures polarization effects though it does not explicitly include adsorbate–solvent interactions like hydrogen bonding. Such limitations may lead to underestimation of stabilization for intermediates that interact strongly with explicit water [23,26,27]. The self-consistent field (SCF) energy convergence criterion was set to 1 x 10–6 eV. Partial occupancies were treated using the Methfessel–Paxton smearing method with a smearing width of 0.2 eV [28]. Brillouin zone sampling was performed using the Monkhorst–Pack grid [29]. Atomic coordinates were relaxed until the forces on each atom were less than 0.03 eV/Å. Details on the construction of the phase-separated Cu–Zn model, Cu(111), and homogeneous Cu3Zn(111) structures are provided in the Supplementary Material. Free energies (G) of adsorbates and gas-phase species were computed using: G = E D F T + Z P E + ∫ C p d T - T S v i b where E D F T is the total energy from DFT, ZPE is the zero-point energy, ∫ C p d T accounts for enthalpic temperature corrections, and T S v i b represents the vibrational entropic contribution of the adsorbates calculated at 300 K. Electron–proton transfer steps were treated using the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) approach [30], incorporating applied potential (U) corrections. Transition states of C–C coupling steps were located using the climbing-image nudged elastic band [31], and dimer [32] methods, and confirmed by the presence of one imaginary frequency. Furthermore, microkinetic modelling (MKM) was carried out for the CO reduction reaction (CORR) [33]. Free energy barriers for all proton-coupled electron transfer steps were set to 0.26 eV, as reported by Tripkovic et al. [34]. C–C coupling steps were assumed to be independent of applied potential. Full details of the MKM framework are provided in Section 3 of Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of phase-separated Cu–Zn Our model for the phase-separated Cu–Zn catalyst is guided by experimental evidence, as reported by Ren et al. It was observed that Cu–Zn (4:1) catalysts exhibit distinct segregation of Cu and Zn phases without alloy formation [13]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) showed signatures of Cu(111) and Zn(002) planes, supported by energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [13–15]. Moreover, prior studies have confirmed the predominance of metallic states in Cu–Zn catalysts under electrochemical conditions [13,35–39]. This phase separation has been consistently linked to enhanced ethanol production in Cu–Zn systems. Upon structural optimization, the Zn10 clusters deposited on Cu(111) transition from a 3D geometry, as observed in its isolated form, to a 2D planar configuration on the surface (Fig. S1), with the most stable form binds entirely to the Cu surface (Fig. 1 a). The surface atomic ratio of our Cu–Zn model is approximately 4:1, which is similar to that of the experimental study [13]. The most stable configuration—where Zn atoms bind entirely to the Cu(111)—is energetically stable, exhibiting only a slight increase in surface energy compared to the Cu3Zn(111) alloy (ΔE = 0.02 eV/Å2; Fig. S1f). While Cu and Zn are thermodynamically miscible [40], many experimental studies demonstrate phase segregation of Cu–Zn catalysts [13,14,35,37,41] and Zn-island formation on Cu(111) [42–44] under various experimental conditions. Surface-sensitive techniques including XRD, EDS, and XPS consistently reveal separated Cu(111) and Zn(002) domains in these systems. In addition, an atomic-scale investigation has shown that Zn preferentially adopts flat, surface-bound geometries on Cu(111) [45]. This tendency is reinforced by the low lattice mismatch (1.6 %) between Zn(002) and Cu(111) [46], which minimizes interfacial strain and promotes 2D growth. These insights support our use of a planar Zn-cluster-on-Cu(111) model to represent phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts and their interfacial reactivity. The interface between Cu surface and Zn cluster creates distinct active sites, categorized as Cu, Zn, and Cu–Zn interface sites. Interface sites include the intermediates adsorbed on (i) both Cu and Zn atoms, (ii) Zn atoms at the cluster edges or corners, and (iii) within 3.0 Å of the Zn cluster (Fig. 1a). To explore the electronic effects, we compared the density of states and d-band centers of Zn and Cu atoms in our model (Fig. 1b). The Zn d-band center is located at lower energy relative to Cu. The d-band center of the uppermost Cu layer downward shifts of 0.15 eV compared to Cu(111), suggesting Zn induces electronic redistribution on nearby Cu atoms, which likely affects adsorbate binding. Bader charge analysis further reveals that Zn donates 1.38 e− to Cu (Fig. S2). These findings are consistent with Reichenbach et al.'s conclusion that Zn clusters transfer charge to adjacent Cu atoms [45]. Interestingly, the Zn-induced charge transfer contrasts with that in Cu–Ag systems, where Cu donates electrons to Ag [9], which may originate from their differences in relative electronegativities [47]. Overall, structural optimization reveals that Zn clusters reorganize into a planar, surface-bound configuration upon deposition on Cu(111), creating the Cu–Zn interface active sites and charge redistribution. These geometric and electronic effects may influence intermediate adsorption energies and have direct implications for CO2RR reactivity. 3.2 CO2 activation and CO2 reduction to CO From the proposed mechanism, Zn is anticipated to act as a primary CO-producing site, with the generated CO subsequently migrating to adjacent Cu sites where further reduction and C–C coupling occurs [13]. Experimental evidence has shown that phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts preferentially produce CO at less negative potentials, followed by C2 products like ethanol and ethylene at more cathodic voltages [13]. To differentiate the roles of each active site, we systematically evaluate CO2 activation and its reduction to CO across Cu, Zn, and interface sites. 3.2.1 CO2 activation on Cu–Zn catalyst The initial step in CO2 reduction involves activation via chemisorption, transforming the linear molecule into a bent, charge-rich intermediate stabilized on the catalyst surface [48,49]. We calculated adsorption energies, geometries, and partial charges for CO2 adsorbed at distinct Cu–Zn sites and Cu(111), as shown in Fig. 2 and Table S1. The strength of CO2 adsorption follows the trend: Cu(111) < Cu < Zn < interface site. Enhanced adsorption correlates with stronger charge accumulation (0.67–1.07 e−) and increased bending of the CO2 molecule (angle range: 122.4°–135.7°) (Table S1). This configuration — with CO2 binding through both C and O atoms — aligns with earlier reports on Cu surfaces [50]. The superior activation on interface sites is likely due to the geometric and electronic effects of low coordination atoms, particularly at Zn edge atoms, consistent with previous findings for Zn surfaces [38]. It is important to note that prior studies have shown that charging CO2 or introducing nearby cations can significantly enhance adsorption strength by stabilizing bent configurations and increasing electron transfer [48,51]. However, our aim was to isolate the intrinsic reactivity of Cu–Zn active sites without external electrostatic effects. The observed differences in adsorption energies across Cu, Zn, and interface sites likely arise from a combination of local geometric and electronic effects. 3.2.2 CO2 reduction to CO on Cu–Zn catalyst After the CO2 activation, CO2 undergoes sequential proton–electron transfers leading to CO production. We assessed the reaction energetics at all relevant sites: Cu, Zn, and interface regions (Fig. 3 ). The *CO formation is facile at the Cu site compared to the others. Notably, *COOH formation — the first reduction step — is most stabilized at the interface, resulting in the change of potential-determining step (PDS). The ΔG PDS is 0.42, 0.20, and 0.58 eV, for Cu, Zn, and interface sites, respectively. The low CO desorption energy suggests that Zn sites (0.05 eV) preferentially produce gaseous CO, consistent with their function as CO promoters. Furthermore, adsorption energy maps (Fig. S3) show that *CO binds most weakly at interface sites (−0.29 eV to −0.48 eV), and strongly at Cu sites (−0.81 eV to −0.88 eV), supporting a spillover mechanism from Zn/interface to Cu for further reduction. Indeed, the spillover of *CO from interface to Cu sites is both thermodynamically (ΔG rxn = −0.41 eV) and kinetically (ΔG ‡ = 0.16 eV) favorable (Fig. S4), similar to Cu–Ag systems [8]. This suggests that interface-generated *CO can effectively migrate to Cu regions, setting the stage for C–C coupling or continued reduction. In addition to the phase-separated structure, we evaluated CO2 reduction to CO on the homogeneous Cu3Zn(111) alloy and Cu(111) (Fig. S5) to compare its behavior with interface sites. Although the ΔG PDS of interface site (0.58 eV) is higher than that of the Cu3Zn(111) alloy (0.23 eV) and Cu(111) (0.29 eV), the CO desorption energy of interface site (0.38 eV) is lower than those of Cu3Zn(111) (0.69 eV) and Cu(111) (0.66 eV), indicating superior CO production at the interface site. The stability of both *COOH and *CO is comparable on homogeneous Cu3Zn(111) alloy and Cu(111). These results reveal the distinct feature of Cu–Zn interfaces in early-stage CO2 reduction steps. 3.3 CO reduction to CH4 Experimental studies have shown that CO is the dominant C1 product on Cu–Zn catalysts, with CH4 forming in smaller quantities under similar conditions [13]. At more negative potentials, CH4 formation increases as ethanol selectivity declines, suggesting shared intermediates between these pathways. Given that Cu(111) favors CH4 production [6,22], we investigated CO reduction to CH4 on both Cu and interface sites of the phase-separated Cu–Zn model. We adopted the *CHO pathway and subsequent hydrogenation, as proposed by Oh et al. on Cu(111) [27,52]. The free energy profiles for *CO reduction to *CH4 at Cu and interface sites are shown in Fig. 4 (a). At Cu sites, the PDS step is *CO → *CHO, requiring ΔG PDS of 0.69 eV — consistent with prior reports identifying this as the potential-limiting step of Cu(111) [27,52,53]. In contrast, the interface site significantly lowers ΔG PDS to 0.29 eV for *CHO → *CHOH step. Beyond *CHOH formation, all remaining hydrogenation steps toward *CH4 are downhill at both sites. These results suggest that the interface site facilitates *CH4 formation by stabilizing key intermediates. The weakened *CO adsorption at the interface (see Section 3.2) likely contributes to the lower energy for *CO-to-*CHO conversion. Moreover, intermediates such as *CHOH, *CH, and *CH2 are more stabilized at the interface than at Cu sites, further promoting *CH4 formation. As illustrated in Fig. 4(b), *CO preferentially adsorbs on Zn edge atoms at the interface, while subsequent intermediates bind to nearby Cu atoms. This spatial separation reflects the cooperative nature of the interface: Zn facilitates *CO formation, and Cu drives further reduction. On Cu sites, most intermediates favor hollow-fcc adsorption, except for *CHO, which prefers the top site. These findings indicate the interface’s dual role in stabilizing intermediates and lowering ΔG PDS, making it a key contributor to *CH4 formation. Importantly, the C1 intermediates generated here — especially *CH and *CH2 — also serve as precursors for C–C coupling steps, which are discussed in Section 3.5. 3.4 Hydrogen evolution reaction The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) competes directly with CO2RR, often suppressing multi-carbon product formation. Hori et al. reported that trace Zn contamination on Cu surfaces increases H2 evolution while reducing hydrocarbon yields [54]. To investigate the HER activity on the phase-separated Cu–Zn catalyst, we evaluated reaction energetics at Cu, Zn, and two distinct interface sites: (a) the bridge between Zn edge atoms, and (b) a hollow site on Cu adjacent to the Zn cluster. As shown in Fig. 5 , HER is most favorable at interface (a) site and least favorable on the Zn cluster. The ΔG PDS values range from 0.04 to 0.30 eV across all sites, indicating that HER is thermodynamically accessible. The *H adsorption energy on the Cu site (−0.11 eV) aligns with reported values for Cu(111) and Cu(100) surfaces (−0.24 and −0.29 eV, respectively) using explicit solvent models [55]. *H prefers hollow-fcc sites on Cu, consistent with prior findings [56]. On Zn, *H adsorption favors bridge sites, although low-coordinated Zn atoms at edges or corners may also stabilize *H [38,39]. High-coordinated Zn(002) surfaces exhibit weak HER activity, with *H adsorption energies around 0.6 eV [57]. These trends underscore the anticorrelation between Zn coordination number and HER activity [38,39,57]. It is important to note that, at the operating potential, the adsorption free energy of *H becomes more negative than that of neutrally adsorbed *CO2 and formation of *CO (ΔG PDS = 0.58 eV), indicating that *H is thermodynamically more stable and likely to reach higher surface coverage under these conditions. This suggests that HER could compete significantly with CO2 reduction at the Cu–Zn interface. Such competitive site occupation may represent a disadvantage for phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts. Since several reports showed that *CO coverage affects the *H adsorption [58–60], more comprehensive evaluations of HER competition should be emphasized in future studies. 3.5 Identification of the C–C coupling steps for C2 production C–C coupling is a crucial step in CO2RR for generating C2 products such as ethylene and ethanol [7,19]. On Cu-based catalysts, this step typically involves coupling between *CO and other C1 intermediates like *CHO, *COH, or *CH2 [6,7,21]. Given that CH4 and C2H5OH production may share common intermediates and diverge at the coupling stage [13], we systematically explored all plausible *CO–C1 coupling reactions on both Cu and interface sites of the phase-separated Cu–Zn catalyst. We evaluated the thermodynamic favorability (ΔG rxn) and kinetic barriers (ΔG ‡) for each coupling pathway (Fig. S6-8). As illustrated in Fig. 6 a and summarized in Table S2, several reactions meet the criteria for feasible coupling: exergonic ΔG rxn and ΔG ‡ < 0.75 eV, which corresponds to a turnover frequency of ∼1 s−1 at room temperature [6,61]. Among all coupling steps, CO–CH coupling at the interface site is the most favorable, with ΔG rxn = −1.28 eV and ΔG ‡ = 0.27 eV. In contrast, the same reaction at the Cu site shows a higher barrier (ΔG ‡ = 0.52 eV), and on the homogeneous Cu3Zn(111) surface (Fig. S9), it is even less favorable (ΔG ‡ = 0.98 eV). This reveals the unique catalytic advantage of the Cu–Zn interface in promoting C–C bond formation. Other feasible pathways include CO–CHOH and CO–CH2 coupling at Cu sites, and CO–CHO coupling at the interface. However, CO–CO and CO–CHO coupling — commonly proposed on Cu(100) and Cu(111) surfaces [23,50,62–64] — are energetically and kinetically less favorable on the phase-separated Cu–Zn model, suggesting a shift in dominant mechanisms due to interface effects. As illustrated in Fig. 6b, the CO–CH coupling product (*CHCO) adopts distinct binding modes depending on the site. At the Cu site, *CO and *CH adsorb on adjacent hollow sites, while *CHCO binds at a three-fold Cu site. At the interface, *CO binds to Zn edge atoms and *CH to nearby Cu atoms, with *CHCO bridging the interface. This cooperative binding stabilizes the transition state and lowers the reaction barrier. To benchmark against Cu(111), we evaluated CO–CH and CO–CH2 coupling via both Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) (Fig. S10) and Eley–Rideal (ER) (Fig. S11) mechanisms. On Cu(111), the LH pathway is preferred, with ΔG ‡ = 0.46 eV for CO–CH and 0.56 eV for CO–CH2. The favored LH pathway is consistent with previous computational reports of Cu(111) [8,65]. However, the interface site on Cu–Zn still offers lower barriers and more stable products, suggesting its catalytic superiority. These results demonstrate that the Cu–Zn interface plays a key role in facilitating C–C coupling reactions for C2 product formation. Among all pathways, CO–CH coupling at the interface site stands out as the most thermodynamically and kinetically favorable, outperforming both Cu sites, Cu(111), and homogeneous Cu3Zn surfaces. The interface also stabilizes key intermediates through cooperative binding configurations. This shift in mechanism — away from traditional CO–CO or CO–CHO coupling — suggests the unique reactivity of phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts. 3.6 Pathways towards ethylene and ethanol While Cu-based catalysts often favor ethylene over ethanol, phase-separated Cu–Zn systems have demonstrated enhanced selectivity toward ethanol. Notably, Ren et al. reported that Cu–Zn (4:1) catalysts achieved nearly twice the ethanol selectivity compared to Cu alone at peak performance [13]. To elucidate this behavior, we investigated the late-stage reduction steps following the CO–CH coupling reaction at both interface and Cu sites. The energy profiles are shown in Fig. 7 , and all adsorbed configurations are depicted in Fig. S12 and S13 for interface and Cu sites, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7a of the interface site, the most favorable ethanol pathway proceeds via *CHCO → *CHCHO → *CH2CHO → *CH3CHO → *CH3CH2O → *CH3CH2OH. Each intermediate is stabilized at the interface, particularly through oxygen binding to Zn atoms. Although *CH3CHO and *CH3CH2OH formation steps are slightly uphill (0.13 eV), they are expected to proceed under applied potential. This pathway aligns with previous studies identifying *CH3CHO as one of key intermediates in ethanol production [8,9,23,66–71]. The a small amount of CH3CHO was also detected on the phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts as well [13,14]. For the ethylene formation, the C–O bond-breaking steps of *CH2CH2O and *CH2CH2OH were identified as potential pathways leading to C2H4 production on the Cu catalyst [23]. In contrast, these C–O bond cleavage steps are thermodynamically feasible but less favorable due to the lower stability of these intermediates relative to those in ethanol pathway. The interface site preferentially stabilizes oxygenated species, promoting ethanol over ethylene — consistent with prior findings that undercoordinated and oxophilic sites enhance ethanol selectivity [69,70,72,73]. At Cu sites (Fig. 7b), the same ethanol pathway is accessible, though intermediates are less stabilized compared to the interface. The *CHCO → *CHCHO step is slightly uphill (0.13 eV), and while C–O bond cleavage from *CH2CH2O and *CH2CH2OH remains exergonic, their formation is less favorable. Additionally, Cu(111) favored the C2H5OH over C2H4 production once *CHCO and *CH3CHO are formed [8,69]. This suggests that Cu sites may still support ethanol formation, but with reduced efficiency relative to the interface. As shown in Fig. S14, all ethanol-related intermediates are more stabilized at the interface than at Cu sites. This enhanced stabilization arises from Zn’s oxophilicity [74] and the cooperative geometry of the interface, which facilitates binding through terminal oxygen atoms. These findings are consistent with previous reports on Cu–Zn [70] and Cu-island catalysts [69]. In summary, the Cu–Zn interface site not only facilitates C–C coupling but also strongly stabilizes oxygen-containing intermediates, favoring ethanol formation over ethylene. The preferred ethanol pathway proceeds via *CHCO and *CH3CHO intermediates, which are more thermodynamically stable at interface sites than at Cu sites. These findings help explain the experimentally observed shift in product selectivity toward ethanol on phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts and highlight the interface’s role in the reaction pathways. 3.7 Energetic and microkinetic analysis of CO2 reduction pathways To further evaluate the product selectivity of the phase-separated Cu–Zn catalyst, we summarized the full CO2RR pathways to CH4 and ethanol and included all the C–C coupling routes for comparison. Fig. 8 a and Fig. S15 presents the free energy profiles at 0 V and −0.69 V vs RHE, while Figs. 8b and c detail the microkinetic results at an applied potential of −0.69 V. From the energetics (Fig. S14), at the interface site, the subsequent ethanol pathway is more favorable than CH4 formation, indicating a thermodynamic bias toward C2H5OH. In contrast, on Cu sites, the CH4 pathway remains dominant. The intermediates leading to *CH4 are thermodynamically more stable than those in the ethanol pathway, suggesting less efficiency for C2 production outside the interface region. To provide kinetics insights beyond energetics, microkinetic modeling was carried out at −0.69 V vs RHE. Proton–electron transfer barriers were approximated at 0.26 eV, consistent with literature [34]. Details of microkinetic modelling are described in Section 3 of Supplementary Material: the reaction energetics and rate equations are listed in Table S3–5, and the calculated reaction rate and surface coverage are in Table S6 and S7, respectively. The interface site plays a critical role in promoting ethanol formation, yielding 31 % C2H5OH alongside 69 % CH4 (Fig. 8b and Table S8). This contrasts sharply with the Cu sites, where CH4 is overwhelmingly dominant (99.99 %) and ethanol formation is nearly negligible (0.01 %). The underlying origin lies in the kinetics of C–C coupling pathways (Fig. 8c). At the interface, CO–CH coupling is the favored C–C bond formation step, accounting for 100 % of C–C coupling events. In contrast, Cu sites distribute coupling events across CO–CH (61.6 %), CO–CH2 (30.6 %), and CO–CHOH (8 %), indicating a less selective and less efficient route toward C2 products. The dominant CO–CH coupling step proceeds with a rate over four orders of magnitude higher than any other C–C coupling pathway (Table S6). This key step drives ethanol production (Fig. 8c and Table S9), revealing the interface’s ability to facilitate C2 pathways. The microkinetic results support the proposed mechanism of CO–CHx coupling on phase-separated Cu–Zn systems [13]. Moreover, these findings are consistent with prior works on Cu–Ag systems, where introducing a CO-generating second metal promotes asymmetric coupling reactions [8,65]. Furthermore, the isotope-labeling study supports the CO–CHx coupling mechanism as a viable path to oxygenates [75]. However, the limitations of current solvation models — particularly in capturing cation/anion effects and the electrochemical double layer — suggest that future studies should incorporate more realistic interfaces to refine kinetic predictions [76]. Overall, both energetics and microkinetic analyses indicate that CO–CH coupling at the Cu–Zn interface is the dominant pathway for ethanol production. While CH4 remains the major product, the interface promotes ethanol formation through asymmetric coupling mechanisms, consistent with experimental observations. These insights reveal the importance of the interface as a strategic design element for optimizing bimetallic Cu–Zn catalysts in CO2RR. 4 Conclusions In this study, we theoretically investigated the role of Cu–Zn interface sites in phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts for CO2 electroreduction to ethanol. Structural optimization revealed that Zn clusters reorganize into planar configurations on Cu(111), forming well-defined interfacial sites that modulate local electronic properties and adsorbate binding. These interface regions stabilize *COOH while destabilizing *CO, thereby promoting the formation of alkyl intermediates and facilitating both CH4 and C2 pathways. Among all CO–C1 coupling reactions, CO–CH coupling at the interface emerged as the most thermodynamically and kinetically favorable, with a significantly lower barrier (ΔG‡ = 0.27 eV) compared to Cu sites (ΔG‡ = 0.52 eV), suggesting the cooperative effect of the interface in facilitating C–C bond formation. In the downstream reduction steps, the ethanol pathway proceeding via *CHCO and *CH3CHO intermediates is more favorable than the ethylene route, with the interface offering enhanced stabilization of oxygenated species. Microkinetic modeling further supported this mechanism, revealing that CO–CH coupling dominates the ethanol formation pathway at the interface, with reaction rates surpassing those of other C–C coupling steps by several orders of magnitude. While CH4 remains the predominant product, the interface significantly enhances ethanol selectivity compared to pure Cu sites. Overall, this work demonstrates the strategic role of Cu–Zn interfaces in steering CO2RR selectivity toward ethanol and offers mechanistic insights for designing advanced bimetallic Cu-based electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic Cu–Zn electrocatalysts have emerged as promising candidates for selectively reducing carbon dioxide (CO2) to ethanol. While CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) has been studied extensively on monometallic Cu and Zn catalysts and their homogenous alloys, the influence of heterogeneous Cu–Zn interfaces remain underexplored. Herein, we used density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the interface effects of phase-separated Cu–Zn catalysts on CO2RR toward ethanol. Interface sites significantly modulate intermediate stability and enhance the C–C coupling step, particularly CO–CH coupling, which is both thermodynamically and kinetically favorable (ΔG rxn = −1.28 eV; ΔG ‡ = 0.27 eV). Interface site favors the ethanol pathway over ethylene after subsequent *CHCO formation. Microkinetic analysis further suggests that CO–CH coupling dominantly contributes to the ethanol production. These findings reveal the cooperative role of interface sites in enabling selective ethanol production, providing insights into the rational design of Cu–Zn electrocatalysts.
